text: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Aman Rakkar of Barclays.
Alison, hopefully, you can hear me okay?
Yes, we can hear you.

Great. I had a question on the ROTE guide for next year, the 14% to 16% range does imply a range of outcomes on profit. I suspect that relates to your view of revenue. But I was interested in where you see the kind of sensitivities to ROTE next year. What gets you to 14% versus, say, 16% next year?

The second was around your assumed interest rate benefit as base rate goes to 2% managed margin benefit of £200 million this year. Thank you very much for that disclosure. I was interested if you can help us understand what you thought a kind of full 12-month run rate for that number would look like? And what kind of deposit pass-through assumption are you embedding as part of that?

Great. Thank you. Well, I'll get to Katie to take you through the detail. But when you look at our rate guidance, I mean, there are a number of drivers to that. Clearly, what we've demonstrated is a well-positioned business and we're growing revenue.

Our transition plan is delivering operating leverage, strong balance sheet and risk diversification and obviously, the capital base with a clear commitment to the capital returns. And so taking that together gives us the ability to strengthen that 14% to 16%. But Katie, do you want to take through a little more detail in that and then the other questions.

Yes, sure. Absolutely. So if I look at the ROCE, there's obviously a number of factors that will impact where we end in that 14% to 16%. And one to think about is the progression of that tangible equity through to the end of '23. So with our announcement today, we've increased the pace on our journey down to our C1 target of the 13% to 14% to get to the -- around 14% by the end of this year.

Clearly, the timing of further distributions from here and when they actually hit tangible equity rate [indiscernible] has a little bit of an impact. RWAs and Ulster, we have around €9 billion of credit RWAs that should roll off in asset sales complete through 2022 and H1 2023. And any residual RWAs there for some of the residual assets in risk, which will take a bit longer in terms of that in. And then for the rest of the group to the Go Forward Group, the drivers on that RWA will be very much loan growth. and any ongoing capital optimization we do.

There's nothing to call out on regulatory deductions in terms of anything on that. When you look at the interest rate benefit, and I'm glad you like the disclosure on Slide 17. I think probably the easiest way to answer your question there is to look at the sensitivity that we've given you on the -- within the accounts and also it's in the appendix of the slide. And what we've also shared with you there is what would it mean in terms of a 100 basis point rise, when we spoke originally, what we have said in that sensitivity is that as rates rise, the pass-through rate would increase. Now that we're up at the level and we're looking at that level above 2%.

We've done an illustrative pass through [15%] of any rate rises as we go forward from here. I would remind you, man, we've only passed the [15%] of the total to date, but that's how we've done the illustration going forward, and we feel that's a relatively good proxy for you to move forward from here.
Our next question is from Rohith Chandra-Rajan of Bank of America. [Operator Instructions]

Again, because I come back to your helpful slide, Slide 17. And I just wondering if you could walk us through that in a little bit more detail in terms of the progression that you've seen in the first half and how the dynamics are different for the second half or for the full year versus what we've already seen in the first half in terms of -- you talked a little bit already about deposit pass-through there is also a lot more hedge benefit coming through as well.

Rohith, thanks very much. Yes. No, look, it's a good side, and we enjoyed kind of pulling it together to try to give you some good guidance. I'll give you a bit of a fuller answer so that you can understand the 3 component parts of that £1.9 billion. Firstly, it's important to remember the margin profile during 2021.

The low point for margin was in Q3 '21 when NIM was 2.28%. And as such, the year-on-year growth will be more significant in H2 than in H1. If I just take the different components first. So the £1.1 billion of managed margin benefit from the base rate at 1.25%. This is effectively the full year benefit from the base rate increases through to June across retail, private and commercial institution institutional, there's been limited pass-through in H1.

We have, as you may know, announced the deposit rate change for our retail customers, which becomes effective on August 1. And following that change, the cumulative deposit pass-through for the group is approximately 15% of the 115 basis point increase in the U.K. base rate since December 2021. If I move to the point to we manage margin benefit, the managed margin benefits for future rate rises 3% to 2% by year-end is based upon our updated interest rate sensitivity disclosure. We've previously discussed how we expect the deposit rate deposit pass-through to be lower for rate increases below 1% and return to a more normalized level and pass-through as we approach that 2% level.

And so for the illustration on this slide, we have assumed the blended pass-through of 50% of each rate rise. So the £200 million reflects the proportionate share of the full year benefit of 325 basis point increases in the second half.

Clearly, the actual benefit depends on the timing and the size of rate rises and also the ultimate level of pass-through, which may vary from the illustration. And then finally, the £0.6 billion of structural hedge benefit that represents the year-on-year increase we expect in total hedge income in 2022. And there's two main factors to think about in there. First of all, we're refinancing at the higher front book rates. We have around £20 billion of maturities in H2 that are rolling off at a yield of around 75 basis points, and they are being invested at the current 5-year spot rate.

And obviously, you'll have seen on the slide as well that we've got increase in notional of £17 billion in the second quarter, and that was invested at a blended rate of 2.5%. And it is important to remember that hedge income in H2 '21 was lower than in H1 '21. And so the year-on-year benefit is greater in the second half of the year as we move forward. Hopefully, Rohith, if that's helped just add a little bit of color to that slide.
Our next question comes from Martin Leitgeb of Goldman Sachs.

Yes. Yes. First of all, congratulation to the strong set of numbers today. I was just wondering if I could follow up on the comment you just made on the 15% pass-through in terms of deposits so far. Is that on deposit within personnel?

Or does this also include commercial. And I was just wondering -- on this slide, you show a meaningful deposit margin benefit in the period from C&I. And I was just wondering, is there any difference in terms of how C&I deposits and deposit pricing will behave going forward as opposed to personnel? And secondly, last quarter, we discussed mortgage pricing and application margins coming back into the 60 basis point range, which now has fed through in terms of completion margin ABS. So was just wondering what you see or what the outlook is in terms of mortgage pricing going forward?
Would you expect current pricing to hold? It seems increasingly swap rates are being passed through? Or could there be a scenario that some of the economics for mortgages shift over to deposit?
Katie, you have to say this.

Yes. No, absolutely. Thanks very much, Martin. So as we look at the pass-through assumptions of what we've done to date, so 15% of the total as we've come through. So limited pass-through across all areas.

What I would say is it does differentiate Martin, across the different sectors. So if you look at the pass-through rate that we've got within our managed rate within retail savings, it's 17%, so an increase of 20 basis points compared to the 115 basis points since the rates have gone through. Within C&I, that is 19% -- 9%, sorry. It's only 10 basis points that have gone through. So you can see that decisions are not uniform across the bank.

We offer also a range of different deposit accounts in terms of things like our digital saver, which offers 3.25% for balances below £1,000. And if you're in a small business space, there's a 40 basis point account as well.

When we look at Q2, the customer funding rate was 10 basis points in retail versus the 5 we had in Q1 and then 9 basis points in C&I versus the 2 basis points that we had in Q1. So there will be a differential rate within there. What we've done in our illustrations is that we've used a 50% illustrative pass-through rates as we move forward. Clearly, it will depend a little bit when the rate rises come through and the timing of those that we do look at our suite of customers and our products and then see what's actually happening in the market as well, which I think is very important to consider. But I think that illustration is a good guide for you to think as you go forward.

Then in terms of the mortgage margin disclosure, what we're trying to do is to lift you a little bit to the NIM guidance for 2022. And Martin, I know that we'll dance around that for a few quarters, and that's fine. We are very much trying to manage both sides of the balance sheet to improve the margins and mortgages is just obviously one part of that. You can still see the disclosure in the financial supplement on the retail banking, sorry, mortgage income as well as the deposit income. And this allows you to see the development of the mortgage margins over time, which for the group book back book declined from 158 basis points to 150 basis points in Q2, driven by that lower completion margins as expected.

Swap rates have continued to move up in the second quarter, and we saw significant movements in there. When we spoke in Q1, I said that we were not happy with our application margins at 44 basis points. and following action on the customer rates, the application margins for the group were above that 60 basis point number that I was aiming for as we got to the end of Q2 with some further widening in July. Martin, your question on how we think it will develop here. But the swap curve has been so volatile over these last sort of 6 months.

And I think what we've seen is the market reacting to it very sustainably in terms of actually taking that customer rate up to deal with the swap rate movements. I think we've kind of got to the right place on now. I think what happens as we go forward from here will obviously depend a little bit in terms of what happens on that swap curve and also kind of wider customer behavior. But I think from our side, we've got the benefit of the strength of the hedge income coming through. So it enables us to absorb some of that volatility should it come through.
Thanks, Martin.
Our next question comes from Alvaro Serrano of Morgan Stanley.[Operator Instructions]

Yes, I think we're good. Just 2 questions. Obviously, the 14% to 16% RoTE is very healthy and nice to see. I wonder beyond sort of the short-term sort of sensitivities in the numbers you've already provided, what do you see the biggest risks in medium term because it does look quite healthy I'm wondering if we're going to perpetuate this value on that 15% ROE. What do you think is the biggest reset competition on deposit side, competition on mortgages, the regulator sort of increasing the pressure on -- maybe on remuneration of deposits?

Or what do you see as the biggest medium-term risk of making too much money if that's, if I can say that. And on costs, just a very on that flat cost guidance for 2023. What CPI are you assuming there? What inflate underlying inflation are you assuming?

Thank you. Well, the guidance we've given you, as you know, we're very thoughtful about when we when we give you guidance and how we look at that. Clearly, as we project forward, clearly, the impacts of cost of living, inflation are challenges. And I think we can see good growth across all of our businesses, but we're not significantly dependent on volume of lending growth as we go forward. I think the biggest risk is we see a slowdown in growth as customers both on the consumer side and the business side, grapple with the challenges of cost of living and inflation, the supply chain disruption that we're seeing.

And that's why we're being so proactive in terms of outreaching to help our customers. And obviously, we're keeping a very close eye on impairments and early warning indicators of stress in the book. But as you can see, we have a well-diversified book predominantly secured and we're well provisioned. So I think as we look forward, the economic uncertainty is really a challenge for growth and having a strong balance sheet sort of answer your question, A strong balance sheet with capital means that we can continue to lend and support our customers through that cycle. And I think that is a positive and an important point of being a well-capitalized, well risk-diversified bank supporting customers.
Katie, do you want to pick up the cost question?

Yes. No, absolutely. So could you look at the sort of inflationary impact on costs, within 2022, we've obviously seen some of that in terms of the wage awards that we put through in 2021 and then implemented in Q2. And the average increase cost and we've now done in July, a further support for our 22,000 employees earning less than £32,000. Those together kind of have come to a kind of increase in salaries of £100 million, as we have them implemented.

And when you see as you move into 2023, we can see that there could be some more pressure on our wages. We also are seeing as many businesses are increases in our contract renewals going up to sale. And even things like a marketing spend, you can see that kind of coming through. So inflation, you reached 9.4% in June. Our expectations is that it will rise to about 8.4 million annually for the whole year.

And so that's really what we're reflecting in terms of that inflation piece. But I think what we try to do is to make sure that we manage it tightly, focus on making sure that the investment spend is available. and that that's protected within that space. And then we continue to drive out the efficiencies as we move forward. So even as we look to '23 while our guidance is flat, there's still significant cost efficiency that has to be delivered to make sure that we can maintain that broadly for that guidance.

Our next question comes from Omar Keenan of Credit Suisse. Omar, you'll have to unmute, otherwise we'll move on to next question, which is Guy Stebbings of BNP Paribas Exane. [Operator Instructions] Or so Omar, is it. Omar, please over to you.
Yes. Sorry about that. Congratulations on a very strong set of numbers and the rate guidance upgrade as well. I've had -- I have two questions, please. One on the impairment guidance for 2023.

And just -- sorry, another one on deposit beta. So firstly, on the impairment guidance for '23 to remain below through the cycle levels. I guess that depends on the base case U.K. economic assumptions that you gave. And I just wondered, given the level of economic uncertainty.

What gave you the confidence at this stage to give a guidance on 2023? Is it the presence of management overlays that give you the comfort to do that when you think about the rent of outcomes that could potentially happen?

And secondly, on the deposit beta, I'm still very surprised at how good it's been in the C&I business. I understand that a lot of the -- as you said before, a lot of the deposits are managed rates, but I still would have thought that there would have been a little bit more pressure upward pressure there. Is there any more color that you can give maybe what the secret sauce is in the C&I business?

Thank you. Well, Katie can take you through the details of our provisioning and impairments. And so what gives us the confidence as we sit here today and as we look forward. Firstly, I think look at the mix in our book. We have a well-diversified book predominantly secured.

92% of our book is secured. We had good risk diversification, so -- and we are well provided for. Also, as we look at the performance of our book, we're not seeing any signs of distress or default or deterioration both in our consumer and business book. And customers have significant liquidity and buffers sitting on both their business and consumer household balance sheet.

So we are actively looking for the size of stress and early warning indicators and there's a very extensive outreach program of proactive to encourage customers to come and talk to us so we can help them manage through. So I think it is a combination of the risk diversification, the active management and the mix of our book. I think probably that's where I would start. And then as you look at provisioning, we are well provisioned. Katie, do you want to maybe give a little bit of color on that?
And then obviously, the deposit points.

Yes. No, absolutely. So what we've done in 2023 is to maintain guidance we've given you previously. And I think that's really important. Building on what Alison says, we're not seeing signs in that -- in those books of strain.

If I can take you a little bit to where we are on the PMA, I think, might be helpful. So we've got various PMAs. The 1 I think that's most interesting is the one for economic uncertainty, £583 million. When we looked at that PMA this quarter, what we've done is released a significant portion that was in relation to COVID.

And then we've also added other items, which are very much in relation to the cost of living and supply chain type issues. And we've done that very forensically. By looking through the bots to where our customers are, who might be impacted by the challenges we think that were coming. So that £583 million gives us some provision for things that are coming down the road. And then the other place I would encourage you to look at is on Page 27 of the accounts, where we show you the sensitivities and what we do there to the extreme downside 100% on that downside.

What you can see in Stage 1 and Stage 2 ECL is to have an increase in our provisions of £969 million. Now with that PMA that you've got with that kind of level of Stage 1 and Stage 2 hit, there will clearly be Stage 3 hits, which we don't provide estimates for. But that kind of all together gets you to a place where you can see that below the cycle guidance actually has got to see some for very significant curation and still be within that guidance. I would kind of encourage you to put those bits together and then also have a look at the flow tables where you can see just the positive progression out of Stage 2 back in Stage 1 is really strong. And then just moving on to your deposits.
So if we look at C&I, C&I deposits are £223 billion, and they are on an average cost loss of 9 basis points, 9 basis points to 125 basis points, I'll leave you to do the math.

And I think the one thing I'd add on your sort of C&I see the secret sauce, we have an incredibly strong franchise, a leading market position in commercial, #1 NPS sector specialists who are dedicated to sectors, so you can deeply understand what's happening, deep relationships and competitive positioning across the ecosystem, I've talked quite often about the U.K. system of SME support. And all of that combines to give us a very strong franchise, and that clearly is part of the balance that you're seeing play in here.
Our next question comes from [Guy Stebbings].

The first one was on RoTE and then a second one on cost. So RoTE, I guess, 14% to 16% is quite striking, especially when the U.K. is expected to at a downturn. I just wondered how sustainable you view that beyond 2023. Is there anything unique about 2023 versus future years?

I guess you're assuming a benign impairment, but you would expect that to jump from that level. Cost pressures maybe build beyond that year, but you would be hopeful a mention of delivering positive jaws. And indeed, one might expect volumes to be stronger beyond 2023, if we're coming out with the silos. I'm just interested if you in sort of high-level thoughts as to whether '22 is unique in any way and sets a high base or if you think that is a return that can be sustained? Or indeed, if we're staying at those sort of levels and peers might eventually get competed down?

And then secondly, on costs, it's a bit of a shift in the guidance of '23, but it's still flat costs facing into inflationary pressures and you're obviously not expecting a markedly different revenue environment. I just wondered whether -- or why flat is the right number? Had you given any consideration whether to invest anymore and see absolute cost at rise given that revenue backdrop in [indiscernible] in RoTE and the capacity to invest that provides. I don't expose you might get to comment at all beyond '23 is to what we might expect in '24. I appreciate we don't have a crystal ball inflation, but is it fair to assume cost of like to rise and decrease in 2024.

Thank you. Well, as you can imagine, I'm not really going to comment beyond 2023. We'll update you on that probably in February next year. I mean, I think on RoTE, nothing unique, nothing special. What I would say is what you're seeing is a consistent delivery of our strategic priorities.

And we're seeing the benefits of the strength of our fires. We're 2 years into stable investment program, which is delivering positive outcomes. And you can see pleasingly as well the growth across the whole part of our franchise. We're seeing growth in all of the key areas that we've strategically focused on. So there is nothing unique, but positive jaws and our commitment to operational leverage, I think, is the key to think about.

On -- and Katie can sort of comment a little bit more on the cost, but your question of -- could we invest more -- there is a point around how much capacity my business CEOs will always ask for more money to invest.

We're being very focused on strategic delivery, making sure that we invest for growth, you can see that 80% of our investment is in data, digital and technology, and you can see the benefits of that coming through. But we are committed going forward to continuing to drive operational through our business, and that will be something that will continue. Katie, do you want to add anything on costs?

No. I think on costs, I think you've done it all. Shall I take the RoTE question. So in terms of the -- in terms of answers to you net this about 2023, but there are a couple of things that are obviously interesting in 2023. You'll be familiar with our Ulster guidance.

A lot of those costs will hit in 2023. So that's actually a bit of a drag. In terms of that number, which is also, I guess, why we've got this range. Clearly, I think you've got to have a view as to where interest rates might go beyond '23. I mean at the moment, we are assuming 22% at the end of this year and then flat into 2023.

But we're comfortable with the range that we've given you is an appropriate range. I'm not going to get drawn on 2024 and 2025, what I'm sure talk more about that to be, but at this stage, we're comfortable we've given you a pretty robust number.
Our next question comes from Chris Cant of Autonomous.

One on sort of balance sheet churn numbers and on asset quality, please. So you mentioned a number on hedge maturities for the second half. Could you give us a sense of the proportion of the hedge, which is rolling into 2023. I think we should be taking something like 20%-ish of the £230 billion if you've been doing it pretty mechanically. But if you could give us a number.

And then against that, obviously, we have this negative churn dynamic on the mortgage book. One of your large domestic peers called out 2023 as a particularly heavy year for mortgage refinancing pain. Do you see a similar lumpiness there into 2023? I suspect you were doing a little less 2-year business back in 2021, [indiscernible] bank, but obviously, it's quite hard for us to assess from the outside. So any color would be appreciated.

And then on asset quality, are you seeing any signs of stride in SME book specifically? So I appreciate the kind of the high-level view as everything is very benign. But if you kind of focus in on the SME exposures you have -- are you seeing any different trends there relative to the broader commercial book, please?

Thank you. So let me pick up the asset quality in SME and then Katie will take you through the other questions. So the short answer is no, we're not seeing any signs of strain. What we are seeing is still relatively muted demand in the small SME side of the book. mainly because of that higher government scheme lending levels in this sector.

And actually, what we can see, Chris, which is interesting, is still around 24% of the bounce back loans sitting on deposits what we obviously do is look at our whole commercial sector really very much by large, mid-corporate and SMEs and we also take a sector lens, but we're not seeing deterioration ores. Clearly, one of the areas we're really focused on is the degree of change of challenges that businesses are facing with supply chain disruption with fuel costs and hedging, which is why we've put this very targeted support out, and I talked this morning about the £1.25 billion we put agriculture, the 42,000 farmers we support. So very short answer, no deterioration. We're obviously keeping a very close eye on it. there's still a lot of liquidity and actually lower demand coming from the SME segment at the moment.

Thanks, Alison. If I just move back to the hedge book. It is very mechanistic hedge rolls off sort of [indiscernible] a month given its 5-year nature. The way I would think of that in 2020, Chris is about roll-off of £35 billion to £40 billion in terms of the amount that would come through. When you also look at the pressure in terms of 2023 around that 2-year business, it's certainly a theme.

But you're right, we have been writing a lot of 5-year business, and we've seen that continue to increase in this year, but even a couple of years ago, we were up above that kind of 60% level. So that kind of helps push it further. I mean, our 5-year share of our mortgages in this quarter was 69% compared to 66% the previous quarter. And we do think that the strength of the investment that we've done this year, it certainly helps offset it in 2022. And I think we've got a relatively positive journey into 2023.
Obviously, it will depend a little bit on customer pricing and what happens in the second half of this year, but we have considered that in our RoTE guidance of the 14% to 16%.
Okay. Great. So nothing in particular call out on mortgage lumpiness?
Yes, absolutely. Thanks, Chris.
Our next question comes from Edward of KBW.
Sorry, I think that's -- is that working?
Yes. We can hear you.

I just had two questions. One was on Ulster and costs. And I guess the indirect costs. Now you're working through the disposals. Are you still reasonably confident of, I guess, what was annualized, almost £200 million of central costs paid by Ulster at the moment, that you're going to find ways of stripping those out.

I guess that would be the first question. And then the second question, yes, about the cost of living prices. I mean, I guess there's a lot of talk politically about the cost of living crisis. look, it's not aimed just at you this question. It's more the sector, but I guess you're a big part of it.

As a sector, you're obviously taking the full benefit of the rate rises. And as we've highlighted passionate none of the downside or none of the benefit to customers, I guess, of the dawn of rising rates, which I guess we've seen in oil sector and various others after all, politicians tend to get quite interested in that. Is there a level at which you start to feel your margins are becoming sort of too big or that you should say, well, actually, we do fairness said that with 20% market share, we should actually share some of the benefits those for savers should actually get more of the benefit than we're giving them today. How do you feel about that in terms of sort of like what is sort of a reasonable margin for a big incumbent to be making?

Thanks. Well, let me take the question on cost of living and interest rates. Clearly, we balance both sides of the balance sheet when we're looking at the return we make. And we're very targeted around making sure we put support in the right areas. At the moment, we're seeing lots of liquidity sitting on household balance sheets and a lot of liquidity still sitting on business accounts as I touched on before.

So we're making our decisions on pass-through rates as well as obviously, what we've seen on the swap curve side and mortgage rates as we look at balancing what is what is the right return? And then very specifically, we're looking at how can we target to support those most in need, you're really going to see the squeeze in cost of living and really having a material impact. And that's where the package of measures that we talk about around proactive support have been put in place £4 million into our hardship funds with our charity partners to help with outreach to around 3 million customers where we think we can do more to help them. We're running [ 5,000 ] financial health checks a week working with our customers, looking at their balance sheets and how we can save them money and help them structure different things. We're freezing tariffs on our business current accounts for 12 months to help SMEs.

And we've also, just thinking about the mortgages proactively helped around 100,000 customers secure new rates by extending our roll-off window. So we look at it in the round of the support for our customers. The thing to remember about the mix of our book as well is we are predominantly a secure book now. 9 out of 10 of our customers are on fixed mortgage rates so we're not having any impact of the rising rates at the moment. So we do look at it in a very balanced way to make sure that we're putting the support in the right place.

And as Katie mentioned, with our pass-through rates, we look at on a product-by-product customer segment by customer segment basis. We've got 40 basis points saving account for small businesses. We've got our digital saver account, paying [ 3.25 ], and we will look at it constantly on that basis and the team will always balance that to make sure we're balancing both sides of our balance sheet and also supporting our customers in the right way.

Should I say of the costs. So if we look at the our guidance when we first spoke about this was a £200 million reduction in their costs between '23 and 2021. So we've -- that's unchanged. We're fully -- so considering the also costs as we give you our RoTE guidance for 2020, both the direct and the indirect. Work is obviously ongoing to deal with both direct and indirect.

And they will certainly be on the indirect side a level of costs that get eliminated. Some, by the way, nature, will stay within the group a little bit as well, but it's something that we feel we're continuing to manage well. And that's all being built into the cost guidance we've given you today for '23 and also the RoTE guidance.

I just thinking, Katie, in terms of you gave us the go-to group or the go-forward group. But that obviously assumes all the indirect costs are out. So I'm just trying to think, is there any risk to that go-forward group number in terms of the base going forward? In the sense that some of those costs actually then have to come back in.
No, we would have considered what might come back in, in terms of that piece in the guidance in the projection that would be fully reflected.
Our next question comes from Jonathan Pierce of Numis.

Just a question, a follow-up actually on one of Ed and up on earlier in the call. The RoTE guidance is obviously impressive. Lloyd's also talking about low [indiscernible] returns moving forward as well. I mean, I guess you [indiscernible].
Jonathan, we're struggling to hear at the moment. So we're going to move on to our next question. I'll come back to Jonathan. [Technical Difficulty]
The high terms of generation on their deposits and what you're generating overnight.
Sorry, we -- your line was absolutely terrible. So we got absolutely none of that. I'm so sorry.
We're going to come back to that question shortly. Andrew Coombs from Citi, if we can go to your question, please.

Two questions and one might be what Jonathan is trying to ask in any case. So Matt's comments just on the whole point about the magnitude of the RoTE. Interested in any discussions you've had with government authorities with regards to the bank tax. Obviously, the previous chance we talked about reducing [indiscernible] alongside the increase in corporate tax rates. But given the act where we head with conceptive leadership contest and interest in any discussions you've had on this, both for yourselves as and the ending of the sector as a whole.

And then the second question would just be on the special dividend that you've announced, clearly much larger than expectation on Slide 26, I think it is you outlined the rationale. But interested in why you have elected to go down special dividend where it's essentially a one-and-done distribution as opposed considering ongoing buybacks where you have the potential benefit of EPS accretion. It sounds like the government's 50% ownership was a barrier to you there, but interested in any comments you have.

Thank you. So, let me -- on the bank tax, no, we've had no discussions and no discussions have happened. And as you know, there are already bank taxes that we pay with the levy, but there have been no active discussions on that. On the special Well, look, we decided to undertake the special and share consolidation for a number of reasons.

As you know, we have a number of different ways in which we can return capital and we see all of them live, but we felt it was appropriate to go the special and share consolidation at this time for a number of reasons. And firstly, it broadly mimics the share buyback, increasing EPS and NAV per share. Secondly, it allows us to return a greater amount of capital, the £1.75 billion rather than a further H2 driver program would achieve. So it gives us the pay distributions that we wanted. And thirdly, it doesn't change the shareholding ownership structure.

HMC gain below 50% was an important milestone for us, and that ensures that we don't disrupt that. So we will continue to use all the tools at our disposal. We felt this was the appropriate route to go at this stage.
